referenceMentions.context: Recently a number of researchers have recognized the importance of uncertainty in automated planning and are developing approaches to address it (e.g., Dean & Wellman, 1991; Hanks, 1990; Kushmerick, et.al, 1993).
Many planners have actions models where the consequences of an action are functions of the situation in which the action was executed (Wilkins, 1988).

metadata.abstractText: This paper examines the problem of constructing belief networks to evaluate plans produced by an knowledge-based planner. Techniques are presented for handling various types of complicating plan features. These include plans with context-dependent consequences, indirect consequences, actions with preconditions that must be true during the execution of an action, contingencies, multiple levels of abstraction, multiple execution agents with partially·ordered and temporally overlapping actions, and plans which reference specific times and time durations.
